scenes.background: You are leading a project team that has just received an urgent assignment requiring a significant amount of work to be completed within a tight deadline. The team is feeling a lot of pressure, and morale is low, with some members showing signs of frustration and anxiety. One of the team members, Alex, says, 'This is impossible! We can't get this done in time.' You suggested taking a short break and coming back with a fresh perspective. [Monica] agreed, but [Bob] still seems skeptical. After the break, [Bob] says, 'Even with a break, I don't see how we're going to manage this.' You encouraged the team to stay focused and work together, showing good self-regulation and motivational skills. [Monica] adds, 'Yeah, we need a better plan or more resources.' Now, [Bob] crosses his arms and says, 'I'm still not convinced this will work. Maybe we need to rethink everything.' You acknowledged both Monica's and Bob's concerns and proposed a collaborative approach to solve the issue. [Monica] looks worried and says, 'I think we need more direction. What if we can't pull this off?' [Bob] sighs and says, 'We might just be setting ourselves up for failure.'
scenes.description: [Monica] fidgets with her pen and [Bob] continues to look skeptical.

options.text: I understand that this is challenging. Let's re-evaluate our plan and see where we can make adjustments. Bob, any specific areas you think need rethinking?
options.analysis: You acknowledged the challenge and proposed re-evaluating the plan, inviting Bob's input. This shows high levels of empathy and social skills.

options.text: We can do this if we stay focused and support each other. We've handled difficult situations before, and we can handle this too.
options.analysis: You encouraged the team to stay focused and support each other, demonstrating good self-regulation and motivational skills.

options.text: Maybe we should consider asking for an extension or additional resources. It might be more realistic given our current situation.
